prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In band 3 we wish to detect the J=3-2 transition to at least a 3sigma significance level. This transition is crucial in establishing any PDR contribution to the CO SLED. Based on the measurements for Mrk 231 (van der Werf et al. 2010) we require a sensitivity of 0.13 mJy to confirm a pure XDR scenario. The models providing contraints on the required sensitivity are discussed in the science and technical case.
In the HST band F814W observations (rest-frame near-UV) our target is a resolved (PSF ~0.1 arcsec) bright point source, whose core is ~0.5 arcsec across. For our study we request a resolution of 0.5 arcsec with recoverable scales up to 4 arcsec. The requested resolution will allow us to examine the distribution of molecular gas in our target and will ensure that the signal from the source can be clearly distinguished from any possible neaby background signals. We require only integrated CO line measurements and therefore the required sensitivity was calculated for a frequency width of 200 km/s, corresponding to a CO line width expected from local studies of similar objects.
We defined an additional baseband to observe the continuum. The estimated data rate is 11MB/s.

In band 6 we wish to detect the J=7-6 transition to at least a 10sigma significance level, which requires a sensitivity of 0.19 mJy. This transition falls near the peak of the CO SLED in a number of local sources (Pereira-Santaella et al. 2013), and therefore should be detected even in the case of non-detection of other CO transitions. The models providing contraints on the required sensitivity are discussed in the science and technical case.
In the HST band F814W observations (rest-frame near-UV) our target is a resolved (PSF ~0.1 arcsec) bright point source, whose core is ~0.5 arcsec across. For our study we request a resolution of 0.5 arcsec with recoverable scales up to 4 arcsec. The requested resolution will allow us to examine the distribution of molecular gas in our target and will ensure that the signal from the source can be clearly distinguished from any possible neaby background signals. We require only integrated CO line measurements and therefore the required sensitivity was calculated for a frequency width of 200 km/s, corresponding to a CO line width expected from local studies of similar objects.
We defined two additional basebands to observe 14CO(7-6) at a high spectral resolution and to observe the continuum using the TDM correlator mode which will ensure moderate data rates (11MB/s). A detection of 14CO(7-6) will allow us to estimate the optical depth probed by CO(7-6).

In band 6 we wish to detect the J=8-7 transition, which is important in determining the CO SLED shape and therefore the nature of the XDR contribution at higher transitions. Based on the measurements for Mrk 231 (van der Werf et al. 2010) we require sensitivity of 0.19 mJy to achieve at least a 10sigma significance level. The models providing contraints on the required sensitivity are discussed in the science and technical case.
In the HST band F814W observations (rest-frame near-UV) our target is a resolved (PSF ~0.1 arcsec) bright point source, whose core is ~0.5 arcsec across. For our study we request a resolution of 0.5 arcsec with recoverable scales up to 4 arcsec. The requested resolution will allow us to examine the distribution of molecular gas in our target and will ensure that the signal from the source can be clearly distinguished from any possible neaby background signals. We require only integrated CO line measurements and therefore the required sensitivity was calculated for a frequency width of 200 km/s, corresponding to a CO line width expected from local studies of similar objects.
We defined two additional basebands to observe 13CO(8-7) at a high spectral resolution and to observe the continuum using the TDM correlator mode which will ensure moderate data rates (11MB/s). A detection of 13CO(8-7) will allow us to estimate the optical depth probed by CO(8-7).

In band 7 we wish to detect the J=9-8 transition, for which we require a sensitivity of 0.32 mJy to achieve at least a 6sigma significance level. This transition is important in determining the CO SLED shape and therefore the nature of the XDR contribution at higher transitions. The models providing contraints on the required sensitivity are discussed in the science and technical case.
In the HST band F814W observations (rest-frame near-UV) our target is a resolved (PSF ~0.1 arcsec) bright point source, whose core is ~0.5 arcsec across. For our study we request a resolution of 0.5 arcsec with recoverable scales up to 4 arcsec. The requested resolution will allow us to examine the distribution of molecular gas in our target and will ensure that the signal from the source can be clearly distinguished from any possible neaby background signals. We require only integrated CO line measurements and therefore the required sensitivity was calculated for a frequency width of 200 km/s, corresponding to a CO line width expected from local studies of similar objects.
We defined two additional basebands to observe 13CO(9-8) at a high spectral resolution and to observe the continuum using the TDM correlator mode which will ensure moderate data rates (11MB/s). A detection of 13CO(9-8) will allow us to estimate the optical depth probed by CO(9-8).

In band 7 we wish to detect the J=10-9 transition, for which we require a sensitivity of 0.32 mJy to achieve at least a 6sigma significance level. Because the J=10-9 transition in this z=2.5 object falls at the edge of an atmospheric window, the total integration time is 1.34h. However, observations of this transition will allow us to obtain a continuous coverage from J=7-6 to J=11-10, which is very important for XDR modelling. The models providing contraints on the required sensitivity are discussed in the science and technical case.
In the HST band F814W observations (rest-frame near-UV) our target is a resolved (PSF ~0.1 arcsec) bright point source, whose core is ~0.5 arcsec across. For our study we request a resolution of 0.5 arcsec with recoverable scales up to 4 arcsec. The requested resolution will allow us to examine the distribution of molecular gas in our target and will ensure that the signal from the source can be clearly distinguished from any possible neaby background signals. We require only integrated CO line measurements and therefore the required sensitivity was calculated for a frequency width of 200 km/s, corresponding to a CO line width expected from local studies of similar objects.
We defined two additional basebands to observe 13CO(10-9) at a high spectral resolution and to observe the continuum using the TDM correlator mode which will ensure moderate data rates (11MB/s). A detection of 13CO(10-9) will allow us to estimate the optical depth probed by CO(10-9).

In band 7 we wish to detect the J=11-10 transition, which will provide a crucial constraint on the best-fitting XDR models. Based on the measurements for Mrk 231 (van der Werf et al. 2010) we require a sensitivity of 0.32 mJy to achieve at least a 6sigma significance level. The models providing contraints on the required sensitivity are discussed in the science and technical case.
In the HST band F814W observations (rest-frame near-UV) our target is a resolved (PSF ~0.1 arcsec) bright point source, whose core is ~0.5 arcsec across. For our study we request a resolution of 0.5 arcsec with recoverable scales up to 4 arcsec. The requested resolution will allow us to examine the distribution of molecular gas in our target and will ensure that the signal from the source can be clearly distinguished from any possible neaby background signals. We require only integrated CO line measurements and therefore the required sensitivity was calculated for a frequency width of 200 km/s, corresponding to a CO line width expected from local studies of similar objects.
We defined an additional baseband to observe the continuum. The estimated data rate is 11MB/s.

In band 4 we wish to detect the J=4-3 transition, which is important in establishing any PDR contribution to the CO SLED. This transition falls near the peak of a PDR component in a number of local sources (Pereira-Santaella et al. 2013), and therefore should be detected even in the case of non-detection of other CO transitions. The models providing contraints on the required sensitivity are discussed in the science and technical case.
In the HST band F814W observations (rest-frame near-UV) our target is a resolved (PSF ~0.1 arcsec) bright point source, whose core is ~0.5 arcsec across. For our study we request a resolution of 0.5 arcsec with recoverable scales up to 4 arcsec. The requested resolution will allow us to examine the distribution of molecular gas in our target and will ensure that the signal from the source can be clearly distinguished from any possible neaby background signals. We require only integrated CO line measurements and therefore the required sensitivity was calculated for a frequency width of 200 km/s, corresponding to a CO line width expected from local studies of similar objects.
We defined an additional baseband to observe the continuum. The estimated data rate is 11MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The FIR dust emission in QSOs is believed to arise from the AGN activity heating a dusty torus and from the on-going star formation activity in dust enshrouded regions. In general, the two contributions cannot be uniquely separated based on the FIR continuum emission alone.
To characterise these two contributions we propose to obtain a CO SLED for an extreme X-ray luminous QSO, for which AGN dust heating is expected to dominate. The anticipated flux measurements will enable us to differentiate between four scenarios dictating the ISM conditions: dominant AGN heating (XDR-like CO SLED), significant star formation heating despite the presence of a powerful AGN (evidence of a PDR component in the CO SLED), a significant mass of cold molecular gas not connected with any on-going star formation activity (a prominent PDR component in the CO SLED) or a low overall molecular gas content (non-detection of some or all CO transitions).
The observed CO SLED will provide orthogonal constraints on the nature of the FIR dust emission in our target.
